natural solution: Therefore, of his first 22 quarters, 12 of them are from this time period, making for $\frac{12}{22} = \boxed{\frac{6}{11}}$ of his coins being from this time period.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes states :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "states 1780 = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1780. n \<le> 2018 \<longrightarrow> states n \<le> 22"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n < 1780 \<or> n > 2018 \<longrightarrow> states n = 0"
shows  "states 1780 / 22 = 6 / 11"
a_0.informal problem: In the year 1780, there were 6 states. For every year between 1780 and 2018, the number of states was no more than 22. In any year before 1780 or after 2018, there were no states. What is the ratio of the number of states in 1780 to the maximum number of states between 1780 and 2018? The answer is $\frac{6}{11}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes coins_total :: real
and coins_1780_1789 :: real
assumes h0 : "coins_total = 22"
and h1 : "coins_1780_1789 = 6"
shows  "coins_1780_1789 / coins_total = 6 / 11"
a_1.informal problem: If there are 22 coins in total and 6 of them were minted between 1780 and 1789, what is the fraction of coins that were minted between 1780 and 1789? The answer is 6/11.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_quarters quarter_1780_to_1789 :: real
assumes h0 : "total_quarters = 22"
and h1 : "quarter_1780_to_1789 = 6"
shows  "quarter_1780_to_1789 / total_quarters = 6 / 11"
a_2.informal problem: If there are 22 total quarters and 6 of them are from 1780 to 1789, what is the fraction of total quarters from 1780 to 1789? The final answer is $\frac{6}{22} = \frac{6}{11}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Roger_quarters :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum Roger_quarters {1..22} = 22"
and h1 : "Roger_quarters 1780 = 6"
shows  "frac (Roger_quarters 1780) (sum Roger_quarters {1..22}) = 6 / 11"
a_3.informal problem: "Roger has a certain number of quarters for each year. The sum of the number of quarters he has for the first 22 years is 22. In the year 1780, he has 6 quarters. What is the fraction of the number of quarters he has in 1780 to the total number of quarters he has in the first 22 years? The final answer is $\frac{6}{11}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
assumes h0 : "states_joined_1780_1789 = 6"
and h1 : "total_states = 22"
shows  "fraction_of_states_1780_1789 = states_joined_1780_1789 / total_states"
and "fraction_of_states_1780_1789 = 6 / 11"
a_4.informal problem: Between the years 1780 and 1789, 6 new states joined the US, making a total of 22 states. What fraction of the total states joined during this period? The final answer is $\frac{6}{11}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes quarters_in_1780s total_quarters :: real
assumes h0 : "quarters_in_1780s = 6"
and h1 : "total_quarters = 22"
shows  "quarters_in_1780s / total_quarters = 6 / 11"
a_5.informal problem: In the 1780s, there were 6 quarters. If the total number of quarters is 22, what is the ratio of the number of quarters in the 1780s to the total number of quarters? The final answer is $\frac{6}{11}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_states :: real
and states_1780_1789 :: real
assumes h0 : "total_states = 22"
and h1 : "states_1780_1789 = 6"
shows  "states_1780_1789 / total_states = 6 / 11"
a_6.informal problem: In the year 1780, there were 22 total states and 6 of them were created between 1780 and 1789. What fraction of the total states were created between 1780 and 1789? The final answer is $\frac{6}{11}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rogers_coins :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. rogers_coins i = (if i \<le> 1789 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<ge> 1780 \<and> i \<le> 1789 \<longrightarrow> rogers_coins i = 1"
shows  "sum rogers_coins {i. i \<ge> 1780 \<and> i \<le> 1789} / sum rogers_coins {i. i \<ge> 1780 \<and> i \<le> 2018} = 6 / 11"
a_7.informal problem: Roger has a collection of coins, each from a different year. He only has coins from the years 1780 to 2018. From the year 1789 onwards, he stopped collecting coins. Thus, he only has coins from the years 1780 to 1789. What is the ratio of the sum of his coins from the years 1780 to 1789 to the sum of his coins from the years 1780 to 2018? The final answer is 6/11.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes quarters_total :: real and quarters_1780s :: real
assumes h0 : "quarters_total = 22"
and h1 : "quarters_1780s = 6"
shows  "quarters_1780s / quarters_total = 6 / 11"
a_8.informal problem: If there are 22 total quarters and 6 of them are from the 1780s, what fraction of the total quarters are from the 1780s? The final answer is $\frac{6}{22}$ or simplified to $\frac{6}{11}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes states_quarters states_decade :: real
assumes h0 : "states_quarters = 22"
and h1 : "states_decade = 6"
shows  "states_decade / states_quarters = 6 / 11"
a_9.informal problem: In a certain decade, 6 states were admitted to the United States. In the same period, 22 quarters, each featuring a different U.S. state, were released. What is the ratio of states admitted to quarters released? The final answer is $\frac{6}{11}$.
